channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2015 The New York Times Company

item.title: As Putin Talks More Missiles and Might, Cost Tells Another Story
item.description: With the relationship between the Kremlin and the West growing more confrontational, a new arms race proceeds, though with less than Cold War vigor.
item.dc:creator: NEIL MacFARQUHAR
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, front and center, spoke Tuesday at the opening of a fair to exhibit Russian arms and military equipment in Kubinka, west of Moscow.

item.title: Balcony Collapse in Berkeley Kills 6 Irish Students
item.description: Seven other people were injured in the accident near the University of California, Berkeley, some seriously, the police said.
item.dc:creator: ADAM NAGOURNEY, MITCH SMITH and QUENTIN HARDY

item.title: As Tensions With U.S. Grow, Beijing Says It Will Stop Building Artificial Islands in South China Sea
item.description: Experts said construction of the islands was all but complete and China will continue to build military installations on them.
item.dc:creator: EDWARD WONG and JANE PERLEZ
item.media:credit: Center for Strategic and International Studies, via Digital Globe
item.media:description: A satellite image from March 16 shows work on an emerging artificial island at Mischief Reef, part of the Spratly Islands, in the South China Sea.

item.title: Far-Right Parties Form Coalition in European Parliament
item.description: The new bloc, which opposes immigration and big government, will be led by Marine Le Pen, the leader of France’s National Front.
item.dc:creator: ALISSA J. RUBIN
item.media:description: Marine Le Pen, the head of France’s National Front, center, and other representatives of European far-right parties at a news conference in Brussels on Tuesday.

item.title: Janine Gibson, a Former Guardian Editor, Will Head BuzzFeed’s British Operation
item.description: Ms. Gibson, who left The Guardian after being passed over for the editor in chief post, will oversee an expansion of BuzzFeed news staff in Britain.
item.dc:creator: RAVI SOMAIYA

item.title: Nasser al-Wuhayshi, Al Qaeda Yemen Leader, Confirmed Dead in U.S. Strike
item.description: Nasser al-Wuhayshi, 38, had led the group’s operations in the country since 2002 and was also the second-ranking leader of the global extremist network.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Al Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula
item.dc:creator: KAREEM FAHIM
item.media:description: The second-ranking official of Al Qaeda, Nasser al-Wuhayshi, in Yemen in 2012.

item.title: Migrant’s Funeral in Berlin Highlights Europe’s Refugee Crisis
item.description: As part of demonstrations happening across the Continent, a reburial was staged for a Syrian woman who died at sea in March.
item.dc:creator: MELISSA EDDY
item.media:description: An imam led a funeral in Berlin on Tuesday for a 34-year-old Syrian woman who died at sea while trying to reach Italy.

item.title: Leak of Pope’s Encyclical on Climate Change Hints at Tensions in Vatican
item.description: The unexpected leak has raised questions about who caused it, whether they meant to embarrass the pope and if it portends larger fights to come.
item.dc:creator: JIM YARDLEY and ELISABETTA POVOLEDO
item.media:description: Pope Francis in St. Peter's Square on Saturday. The leak of his environmental encyclical has raised questions about whether those behind its publication had set out to embarrass him.

item.title: Hong Kong Election Plan Appears Unlikely to Win Lawmakers’ Approval
item.description: Lawmakers are set to decide that, rather than accept an election plan in which all candidates must effectively be approved by Beijing, they would rather have no direct election at all.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL FORSYTHE and ALAN WONG
item.media:description: Police officers outside the Legislative Council in Hong Kong on Tuesday. Lawmakers are set to reject a plan vetted in Beijing that would change the way this former British colony selects its top official.

item.title: ISIS Loses Control of Crucial Syrian Border Town
item.description: Kurdish rebel fighters, helped by American-led airstrikes, took the town of Tal Abyad, which ISIS had used to smuggle in fighters and supplies.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: BEN HUBBARD
item.media:description: The black flag of the Islamic State, left, flew over Tal Abyad, Syria, on Tuesday. After Kurdish and rebel fighters took over the town later Tuesday, they hoisted a Kurdish militia flag.

item.title: Tsipras Attacks Greece’s Creditors as Pressure Grows on Debts
item.description: The prime minister said austerity measures were humiliating and strangling his people as a meeting of European finance ministers neared.
item.dc:creator: JAMES KANTER and NIKI KITSANTONIS
item.media:description: Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras of Greece addressed lawmakers in Athens on Tuesday.

item.title: Migrant Workers in Dominican Republic, Most of Them Haitian, Face Deportation
item.description: Undocumented workers in the Dominican Republic have until Wednesday to register their presence in the country, in the hope of ultimately being allowed to stay.
item.dc:creator: AZAM AHMED
item.media:description: Haitian migrant workers demonstrated in front of the Haitian Embassy in Santo Domingo, Dominican Republic, this month.

item.title: Egyptian Court Confirms Death Sentence for Ousted President Morsi
item.description: Mohamed Morsi’s sentence was among more than 100 handed down last month by the same court after two sweeping mass trials.
item.dc:creator: DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK
item.media:credit: Ali Malki/Almasry Alyoum, via European Pressphoto Agency
item.media:description: Mohamed Badie, the spiritual leader of the Muslim Brotherhood, center right, was among the defendants in the Cairo courtroom on Tuesday.

item.title: Tunisian Train Hits Truck Blocking Tracks, 18 Dead
item.description: A Tunisian passenger train smashed into a semi-trailer truck racing to cross the tracks early Tuesday morning, killing 18 people as two carriages derailed.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Failure of Obama’s Trans-Pacific Trade Deal Could Hurt U.S. Influence in Asia
item.description: The death of the Trans-Pacific Partnership would be a new setback for American economic diplomacy in the region after a failed attempt to thwart a Chinese state-run infrastructure investment fund.
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.dc:creator: JONATHAN SOBLE
item.media:description: Workers harvesting lychees in Luc Ngan, Vietnam. President Obama argues that a Pacific Rim trade pact would require the Vietnamese government to improve employee safety.

item.title: Tracing a 17-Year-Old’s Path From Britain to an ISIS Suicide Attack
item.description: Talha Asmal, a student from West Yorkshire, would be his country’s youngest known suicide bomber if his role in an attack in Iraq is confirmed.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: KATRIN BENNHOLD
item.media:description: Talha Asmal, a British teenager who apparently detonated a car full of explosives at Iraq’s largest oil refinery, in an image posted on a militant website.

item.title: Ligny Journal: 200 Years After Waterloo, Napoleon Still Wins by Losing
item.description: As Europe observes the Waterloo bicentennial, the legend of the defeated emperor continues to draw crowds while Wellington, the victor, is often forgotten.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW HIGGINS

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: What You Need to Know About the Vote on Hong Kong’s Election Rules
item.description: Hong Kong lawmakers are to begin debating on Wednesday a Beijing-backed proposal to change how the city selects its top official. We offer a primer on the issues.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: Pro-democracy demonstrators outside the Legislative Council in Hong Kong on Monday night.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Q. and A.: Holden Chow on China, Elections and Hong Kong’s Attitude
item.description: Mr. Chow, of the pro-Beijing Democratic Alliance for the Betterment and Progress of Hong Kong, said it would be a mistake to vote against a proposal to allow all those eligible to cast a ballot in the 2017 election for the city’s top leader.
item.category: Democratic Alliance for the Betterment and Progress of Hong Kong
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL FORSYTHE
item.media:description: Holden Chow, vice chairman of the Democratic Alliance for the Betterment and Progress of Hong Kong.

item.title: Kurds Capture Key Islamic State-Held Border Town in Syria
item.description: Kurdish fighters took full control of the border town of Tal Abyad on Tuesday, dealing a major blow to the Islamic State group's ability to wage war in Syria by cutting off a vital supply line to its self-proclaimed capital of Raqqa.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS
